------=_NextPart_000_013C_01CA9AB8.BA152B90
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The pattern that appears at the outputs is under-determined when there are
recurrent cycles.  You can wait (but you don't know how long, as in Colin's
fixed number of iterations), or use an in-recurrence flag or token.  Greedy
BFS, Dijkstra, or Bellman-Ford can be used to identify recurrent cycles.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Thursday, January 21, 2010 3:37 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Resolving recurrent structure.


  

2010/1/21 snapmedown <snapmedown@yahoo. <mailto:snapmedown%40yahoo.com> com>
>
> I haven't found the method by which NEAT resolves recurrent structures. A
quick point in the
> right direction would be helpful.
>

Not sure if this is what you mean but the evolved networks that are
recurrent aren't resolved in any way at all. What happens is that an
activation scheme is required to use them, some simple schemes would
be:

A) Activate for some fixed number of iterations.
B) Activate until the network is relaxed. E.g. until the change in
output value of all nodes is within some threshold.
C) (A) but with the fixed number of activations determined by
analysing the network and calculating its maximum depth, such that we
can get at least some signals all the way from the input nodes to the
outputs.

Colin





------=_NextPart_000_013C_01CA9AB8.BA152B90
